headline: Private-Credit Warning Signs Flash After Blue Owl Unloads $1.4 Billion in Assets
summary: Wall Street has been eagerly selling private credit as a hot opportunity for individual investors.  Blue Owl Capital  a poster child for the industry, said it is liquidating $1.4 billion in assets to raise money to pay out individuals who bought into some of its funds in their heyday but now want to get out.  Stocks across the private-fund industry slid as the deal raised questions about how much fund managers can count on individuals to stay invested in hard-to-sell assets for the long term.

Blue Owl Capital  a poster child for the industry, said it is liquidating $1.4 billion in assets to raise money to pay out individuals who bought into some of its funds in their heyday but now want to get out.  Stocks across the private-fund industry slid as the deal raised questions about how much fund managers can count on individuals to stay invested in hard-to-sell assets for the long term.

headline: Wall Street ends down as private equity stocks sink
summary: STORY: Wall Street's main indexes ended lower on Thursday, with the Dow losing more than half a percent, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq each losing about a third of a percent.Shares of private capital firm Blue Owl slid about 6% after the company said it would sell $1.4 billion in assets and freeze redemptions at one of its funds to manage debt and return capital.The company's troubles weighed on shares of Apollo Global Management, Ares, KKR and Carlyle Group as investors worried about credit quality and lenders' exposure to software stocks. The risk of contagion, especially to public banks, presents a deeper fear, said Leah Bennett, chief investment strategist at Concurrent Investment Advisors."If people are not willing to lend to private companies, and we end up having problems where underwriting isn't looked at the right way, and we've been too loose on our standards, then that causes banks overall and lenders to get very conservative. And they end up just lending to the companies that have the best balance sheets, and usually that causes a retraction and the economy overall, and that's ultimately what keeps me up at night. So whenever we see these themes come up, whether or not it's can Oracle borrow money for their data centers, can AI raise money, private credit - are there issues there? They're all intertwined. It's how healthy is the economy and our lending system, and will the economy contract at a very rapid rate? And that's ultimately what my concern is."Among other stock moves, Deere & Co jumped more than 11% after the farm-machinery maker raised its annual profit forecast and beat first-quarter results estimates.Shares of advertising giant Omnicom jumped 15% after the company beat analysts' estimates for fourth-quarter revenue.And shares of software provider EPAM Systems plunged 17% after its cautious first-quarter outlook disappointed investors.

And they end up just lending to the companies that have the best balance sheets, and usually that causes a retraction and the economy overall, and that's ultimately what keeps me up at night. So whenever we see these themes come up, whether or not it's can Oracle borrow money for their data centers, can AI raise money, private credit - are there issues there? They're all intertwined. And that's ultimately what my concern is."Among other stock moves, Deere & Co jumped more than 11% after the farm-machinery maker raised its annual profit forecast and beat first-quarter results estimates.Shares of advertising giant Omnicom jumped 15% after the company beat analysts' estimates for fourth-quarter revenue.And shares of software provider EPAM Systems plunged 17% after its cautious first-quarter outlook disappointed investors.

headline: Heard on the Street Recap: A Blue Note on Private Credit
summary: This added to concerns that have been building around the lack of transparency in private investments: whether they are really suitable for everyday investors and their exposure to sectors such as software that could be disrupted by advances in artificial intelligence.  Blue Owl Capital, Apollo Global Management, Blacksone and TPG all fell by 5% to 6%.  Blue Owl Capital is now down around 50% over the last 12 months.

headline: Blue Owl Move to Curb Redemptions at Private Credit Fund Hits Alt Manager Stocks
summary: Blue Owl Capital’s  move to halt quarterly redemptions at one of its private-credit funds is hitting the asset manager’s shares and those of other alternative managers, including Blackstone,  Ares Management  and  Apollo  Global Management, that are active in private credit.  The action involving a relatively small fund targeted to retail investors run by Blue Owl is depressing the alt industry managers because of concern that redemptions could be curbed at other private-credit funds that are similar to the affected Blue Owl fund,  Blue Owl Capital  II, which isn’t publicly traded.  The largest nontraded private credit fund is Blackstone Private Credit, with about $47 billion in net assets, followed by Blue Owl Credit Income at $19 billion of net assets, and Apollo Debt Solutions at $14 billion, according to data from Raymond James analysts.

The largest nontraded private credit fund is Blackstone Private Credit, with about $47 billion in net assets, followed by Blue Owl Credit Income at $19 billion of net assets, and Apollo Debt Solutions at $14 billion, according to data from Raymond James analysts.
